# Outline

* Surveys assess public opinion
* Survey experiments test reactions to treatments
* Only as good as the measurement techniques we use
* Ordinal variables
    + Ordered categorical variables with unevenly spaced distances
    + Important EV in political science is ordinal (education)
* Current common practice makes unwarranted assumptions
* Fill the gap: Ordered probit approach with latent continuous structure
* Chapter II: Blocking in Survey Experiments
* Chapter III: Missing Data Solutions in Surveys
* Chapter IV: Morality, Self-Interest, and Frame Strength

\pdfnote{I am interested in public opinion. That means surveys and survey experiments}
\pdfnote{Important measurements: question wording, mode how the questions are asked}
\pdfnote{Other ordinal pol sci EVs: anything with a Likert scale (support for candidate, views on issues)}

# 
\centering \LARGE \textcolor{pigmentblue}{Ordinal Variables and Proposed Ordered Probit Approach}


# Ordinal Variables

* Categorical variables: Nominal, interval, ordinal
* Nominal (e.g. race)
    + Not intrinsically ordered
    + Often made binary
* Interval (e.g. income)
    + Ordered, evenly spaced categories
    + Often made numerical
* Ordinal
    + Ordered, unevenly spaced categories
    + Often made binary or numerical
* Problems
    + Binary conversion assumes arbitrary ordering
    + Numerical conversion assumes evenly spaced categories
    + Both can lead to inversions of effects and Type I/II errors
    


# Ordered Probit Approach

* Probit/logit models widely spread
* Most suggest quantifying non-quantitative variables according to their empirical distributions
* Assumes presence of continuous underlying variable
* Uses ordinal information provided and respects uneven distances 
* Literature focuses on ordinal variables as outcome variables
* I estimate continuous distribution to then use for further analysis

# Tests and Results

* Block 2016 ANES on education into 3 treatment groups twice: Once for OP categories, once for ANES categories
* ANOVA + GLM regressions
    + One regression per treatment group: Variable $\sim$ Education Set
    + No significant differences between sets for numerical variables
    + Significantly different intercepts for factor variables
* Block into 2 treatment groups twice
* Placebo OLS regression
    + $\text{Feel Trump}_i \sim \,\beta_0 + \beta_1 \text{Group}_i + \beta_2 \text{Democrat}_i + \beta_3 \text{Republican}_i \,+$ \begin{sloppypar}
\hspace{2.3cm}$\beta_4 \text{Income}_i + \beta_5 \text{Male}_i + \beta_6 \text{White}_i + \beta_7 \text{Black}_i \,+$\\
\hspace{2.3cm}$\beta_8 \text{Hispanic}_i + \epsilon_i$\end{sloppypar}
    + OP `Group` distribution closer to expected zero than ANES
* Re-estimation of categories potentially meaningful

\pdfnote{Placebo: All binary except income. Possible additions: age, occupation}
\pdfnote{Placebo: mean 0.019 vs. -0.05; median -0.01 vs. -0.07}

\centering \LARGE \textcolor{pigmentblue}{Chapter III: Quality Comparison of Major Missing Data Solutions with a Proposed New Method for Ordinal Variables}


# Missing Data Solutions

* State of the art: multiple imputation
* Multiple hot deck imputation more precise for discrete data
    + Preserves integrity of discrete data
    + Does not change size of standard errors
    + Estimates affinity scores for each missing value to measure similarity
* But:
    + Does not account for ordinal variables
    + Algorithm for affinity score based on evenly spaced sequential numbers
* Apply ordered probit approach to multiple hot deck imputation

\pdfnote{hot decking: Taking draws from a deck of computer punch-cards}
\pdfnote{Why `hot.deck` as basis? Made for discrete data in surveys, keeps data integrity intact}
\pdfnote{MI: Impute from conditional distribution $m$ times. Analyze results. Combine results}
\pdfnote{amelia: For continuous imputation treatment, no need to specify ord vars with `ords`. Recommends using continuous non-integers for analysis, even though they sometimes don't make sense} 

# `hd.ord`: Multiple Hot Deck Imputation with Ordinal Variables

* Apply `polr` to estimate cutoff thresholds
* Calculate mid-cutpoints for each newly estimated category
* Scale mid-cutpoints
* Use scaled mid-cutpoints to measure distances for affinity scores
* Illustrative example:

\pdfnote{mice: Ordered with more than two levels uses `mice.impute.polr`, which calls `polr`}
\pdfnote{So no specific treatment for ordinal variables in mice}


# Tests and Results

* Ampute complete CCES and ANES data
* Impute with `mice`, `amelia`, `hot.deck`, `hd.ord`; also use `na.omit`
* MAR and MNAR for 5 variables with NA, increased number of ordinal variables, increased missingness
* Test for accuracy and speed for binary, ordinal, interval variables 
* `hd.ord` worse than `mice` and `amelia` in many cases, but on par in others (binary variables in data MNAR)
* Gain in speed somewhat negligible

\pdfnote{hd.ord under 3 mins, amelia more than 3 times slower (9 mins), mice more than 19 times slower (50 mins)}
\pdfnote{Times for 1,000 iterations of imputations}
\pdfnote{2.2 times and 12.3 times slower for 50 percent NA}

# 
\centering \LARGE \textcolor{pigmentblue}{Chapter IV: Morality, Self-Interest, and Frame Strength}


# Framing

* Presenting an issue to affect the way people see it
* Reorganizes existing information already present and directs attention to particular considerations
* Frames can have substantial influence on people's opinions
* Uncover which types of frames have more influence than others
* Test influence of morality and self-interest in political framing


# Experiment Design

* Online, Lucid, 2,165 respondents
* Morality: foundation of Care/Harm
* Self-interest: personal autonomy, health/safety, wealth, status
* Issues: healthcare, environment
* 5 frames (2 supporting, 2 opposing, 1 control)
* Hypotheses
    + \textbf{H1}. Moral frames move people more than self-interest frames
    + \textbf{H2}. Moral frames move people with higher morality scores more than people with lower morality scores
    + \textbf{H3}. Self-interest frames move people with higher self-interest scores more than people with lower self-interest scores
* Respondents blocked on education for ANES and OP set (chapter II method)
* Missing data inserted and imputed (chapter III method)

\pdfnote{Haidt has 6 foundations: Fairness/Cheating, Loyalty/Betrayal etc., Table 4.1}

# Results

* \textbf{H1}: Reject null for opposing frames, fail to reject for supporting frames
* \textbf{H2}: Reject null for high morality opposing, fail to reject for supporting
* \textbf{H3}: Fail to reject null
* Methods application:
    + No substantive differences between blocked sets of categories
    + `hd.ord` performs worse than `amelia`, `mice` for missing data


#
\centering \LARGE \textcolor{pigmentblue}{Conclusion}

# Conclusion

* Attempt to use unique information provided in one of most important predictors of political behavior to measure what people think as well as possible
* Focus on keeping integrity of the discrete data intact
* Evidence points against endorsing my ordered probit approach
    + Blocking shows mixed results
    + `hd.ord` does not improve on current multiple imputation methods in many cases
    + No substantive differences in framing results
* Take away
    + On par results for blocking
    + Method might work for certain specific cases of missing data (MNAR, binary variables)
    + Morality (Care/Harm) plays role in frame influence regarding things we oppose

\pdfnote{Estimating the latent underlying continuous variable underneath education, estimating cutoff thresholds between the education categories, and binning observations according to linear model predictors to obtain a new set of education categories based on data fit does not appear to improve upon current research practice}
\pdfnote{Next: Develop some form of diagnostic test when ord vars benefit from such treatment and when they don't}
\pdfnote{Other fields (biomedicine, aptitude tests), perhaps weighting, surveys in comparative (seems to work in Jeff's paper), ordinal treatment variables (Mike's 2011 paper)}

# 
* $\bm{X}$: $n \times k$ matrix of explanatory variables
* $\bm{Y}$: observed on ordered categories $\bm{Y}_i \in [1,\ldots,k]$, for $i=1,\ldots n$
* Assumption: $\bm{Y}$ produced by unobserved latent continuous variable $\bm{Y^{cont}}$ on $\mathfrak{R}$ from $-\infty$ to $\infty$
* 'Response mechanism' for $r^{th}$ category: $Y=r \Longleftrightarrow \xi_{r-1} < Y^{cont} < \xi_r$
* Thresholds on $R$: $Y^{cont}_i: \; \xi_0 \underset{a=1}{\longleftarrow\!\longrightarrow} \xi_1 \underset{a=2}{\longleftarrow\!\longrightarrow} \xi_2 \underset{a=3}{\longleftarrow\!\longrightarrow} \xi_3\ldots \xi_{A-1} \underset{a=A}{\longleftarrow\!\longrightarrow} \xi_A$
* $\bm{Y^{cont}}$ determined by linear model of explanatory variables, $Y^{cont} = X \beta + \mu$
* Thresholds on $\mathfrak{R}$ partition variable into regions corresponding to ordinal categories
* Linear model $\bm{Y^{cont}}$ bins observations between thresholds according to predictors

#
* $\bm{X}$: $n \times v$ matrix with data on $n$ respondents for $v$ variables
* $\bm{X}$ formed of missing, $\bm{X^{miss}}$, and observed data, $\bm{X^{obs}}$
* Vector of unknown parameters $\bm{\theta}$
* $\bm{X}$: Random sample from $z$-variate multivariate distribution, $\bm{Z}(\bm{X} | \bm{\theta})$
* Question: How to estimate multivariate distribution of $\bm{\theta}$
* Chained equations model: Estimate posterior distribution of $\bm{\theta}$ by sampling from conditional distributions:

\vspace{-0.8cm}
\begin{align}
Z(X_1 &| X_{-1}, \theta_1) \nonumber\\
&\vdots \nonumber\\
Z(X_z &| X_{-z}, \theta_z) \nonumber
\end{align}

\vspace{-0.3cm}
* Iteration $n$ of chained equations is Gibbs sampler
* Chain starts from random draw from observed marginal distributions
* $\bm{X_i^{(n)}} = (\bm{X_i^{obs}}, \bm{X_i^{*(n)}})$ is the $i$th imputed variable at iteration $n$

# 
* $\bm{X^{obs}}$ and $\bm{X^{miss}}$) are MVN, $\bm{X} \sim \bm{N_v}(\mu, \sum)$
* Vector of unknown parameters $\bm{\theta}$ with $\bm{\theta} = (\mu, \sum)$
* Missingness matrix $\bm{R}$; likelihood of observed data $\text{prob}(\bm{X^{obs}}, \bm{R} | \bm{\theta})$
* MAR assumption: $\text{prob}(\bm{R} = 0 | \bm{X^{obs}}, \bm{\theta})$
* Likelihood under MAR assumption:

\vspace{-0.8cm}
\begin{align}
\text{prob}(X^{obs} | \theta) = \int \text{prob}(X | \theta) x X^{miss} \nonumber
\end{align}

\vspace{-0.6cm}
* Posterior:

\vspace{-0.8cm}
\begin{align}
\text{prob}(\theta | X^{obs}) \propto \text{prob}(X^{obs} | \theta) = \int \text{prob}(X | \theta) x X^{miss} \nonumber
\end{align}

\vspace{-0.4cm}
* Take draws from posterior by combining EM and bootstrapping:
    + Bootstrap data to simulate estimation uncertainty for each draw
    + Run EM algorithm to find mode of the posterior bootstrapped data
    + Impute by drawing from $\bm{X^{miss}}$ conditional on $\bm{X^{obs}}$ and draws of $\bm{\theta}$

# 
* Affinity scores $\bm{\alpha_{co}}$ (each 0-1)
* measure similarity between recipient $c$ and potential donor $o$
* Vector $(p, v)$ with $p$ the DV and $v$ a vector of discrete EVs of length $k$
* If recipient $c$ has $q_c$ missing values in $v_c$, then potential donor vector $v_o$ has between 0 and $k-q_c$ exact matches with $c$
* $w_{co}$: Number of variables where $c$ and $o$ have non-identical values
* Thus $k-q_c -w_{co}$: Number of variables where they have identical values
* Scaled by highest number of possible matches $(k-q_c)$ shows affinity score:

\vspace{-0.7cm}
\begin{align}
\alpha_{co} = \frac{k-q_c-w_{co}}{k-q_c} \nonumber
\end{align}

\vspace{-0.3cm}
* Close potential donors for $h$th variable treated differently from distant ones
* 'Close': $v_{o[h]}$ and $v_{c[h]}$ in same concentric standard deviation from $\overline{h}$
* Values outside of range penalized while values within range count as matches
